author: Jamie Seidel
title: Flinders University chemistry professor Colin Raston awarded Ig Nobel Prize | DailyTelegraph
text:
AN Australian researcher has serious egg on his face. He’s just been awarded the most notorious international prize in science — the Ig Nobel Award — for finding a way to unboil an egg.
Flinders University chemistry professor Colin Raston and his team have built a machine which can unravel proteins. To demonstrate its potential, they fed it a boiled egg.
They got an ‘uncooked’ one back.

Then the Ig Nobel Prize committee came along.
The Igs are intended to reward scientific advances that make people laugh — and think. So, each year, they track down the most unusual and imaginative research.
Despite the seemingly silly act of ‘unboiling’ an egg — though who hasn’t over-boiled one on occasion — it was actually a serious demonstration of a groundbreaking new technology.
It’s a new way of doing chemistry that has implications for cancer treatments, pharmaceutical manufacturing and the processing of biofuels and foods.
“It’s not what we set out to do, to unboil an egg,” Professor Raston says, “but it’s the way of explaining the science involved and helping the wider world realise the momentousness of it.”
It’s also potentially significant in terms of economics: remember, it was an Australian astrophysicist tinkering with radio waves who invented the now ubiquitous technology behind wi-fi.
How to unboil an egg “The sheer scale of this is mind boggling,” Professor Raston says.
“The global pharmaceutical industry alone is worth $160 billion annually and the processing of proteins is central to it. The VFD is completely changing it — and is set to do the same for the fuel and food industries. It’s impossible to place a price on the value of this device.”
The science behind unboiling an egg is just as mind-boggling.
It’s called Vortex Fluidic Technology . Essentially, it’s a way of using mechanical energy (spinning) to undo the work of thermal energy (cooking).
Heat breaks up the bonds of proteins, which settle back into a more tightly bound mass. Professor Raston’s idea is to spin those bound proteins so fast that they fly apart again — but this time, without heat, they snap back to their original shapes.
Flinders University Vice-Chancellor Colin Stirling says Professor Raston’s research is already improving people’s lives.
“His VFD (is) boosting the potency of a common cancer drug fourfold — meaning better treatment with fewer side effects. And that’s just the start,” Professor Stirling Says.
So can you expect a new kitchen gadget any time soon?
No: It won’t work with a whole egg and its shell. Nor does it work if you add any extra ingredients — yet.
And the whole egg-thing was just a demonstration, anyway.
“Winning an Ig recognises the science and is both humbling and amazing” he says.
“It’s living the dream. All scientists want to do something that is significant, but this has the wow factor.”
 Aussie researcher wins Ig Nobel Prize
